poem:
### A Room Without Dreams

In the cramped confines,  
childhood fades like whispered  
echoes. Ezaan carries  
the weight of borrowed walls,  
rooms transient as clouds.  
His laughter, imprisoned  
amid the cold geometry  
of hostel brick,  
searches for skies unknown,  
where roots might lilt  
their tales of home  
in the language of belonging.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It feels very much like a prison’: inside a cramped Birmingham homeless hostel Three-year-old Ezaan has been homeless his entire life. Instead of making memories in a childhood home, he has spent his formative years stuck in hotels and a cramped student dorm. His mother, Sumaira Fareed, was made homeless more than three years ago. She was asked to leave her single persons hostel – where children were not allowed to live – after giving". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
